questions.question:
What is the output printed by the following C code?

 #include < stdio.h >
int main ()
{
    char a [6] = "world";
    int i, j;
    for (i = 0, j = 5; i < j; a [i++] = a [j--]);
    printf ("%s\n", a);
}


(GATE IT 2008)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Consider the following C program that attempts to locate an element x in an array Y[] using binary search. The program is erroneous.

 1.   f(int Y[10], int x) {
2.     int i, j, k;
3.     i = 0; j = 9;
4.     do {
5.             k =  (i + j) /2;
6.             if( Y[k] < x)  i = k; else j = k;
7.         } while(Y[k] != x && i < j);
8.     if(Y[k] == x) printf ("x is in the array ") ;
9.     else printf (" x is not in the array ") ;
10. }
The correction needed in the program to make it work properly is

(GATE CSE 2008)
options:
A.

Change line 6 to: if (Y[k] \(\lt\)x) i=k+1; else j=k-1;

B.

Change line 6 to: if (Y[k]\(\lt\)x) i=k-1; else j=k+1;

C.

Change line 6 to: if (Y[k] \(\leq\)x) i=k; else j=k;
questions.correct_answer:
A.

Change line 6 to: if (Y[k] \(\lt\)x) i=k+1; else j=k-1;
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Consider the following C functions:

int f1(int n)
{
  if(n == 0 || n == 1)
    return n;
  else
    return (2*f1(n-1) + 3*f1(n-2));
}
 
int f2(int n)
{
  int i;
  int X[N], Y[N], Z[N] ;
  X[0] = Y[0] = Z[0] = 0;
  X[1] = 1; Y[1] = 2; Z[1] = 3;
  for(i = 2; i <= n; i++)
  {
    X[i] = Y[i-1] + Z[i-2];
    Y[i] = 2*X[i];
    Z[i] = 3*X[i];
  }
  return X[n] ;
}
f1(8) and f2(8) return the values

(GATE CSE 2008)

questions.question:
What is printed by the following C program?

 int f(int x, int *py, int **ppz)			
{						                    	
    int y, z;					                		
    **ppz += 1; z = **ppz;		                
    *py += 2; y = *py;					                	
    x += 3;					                    	
    return x+y+z;
}

void main()
{
    int c, *b, **a;
    c = 4; b = &c; a = &b;
    printf("%d", f(c, b, a));
    	
}


(GATE CSE 2008)

questions.question:
Study the following program

//precondition: x>=0
public void demo(int x)
{
    System.out.print(x % 10); 
    if (x % 10 != 0)
    {
        demo(x/10);
    }
    System.out.print(x%10);
}

Which of the following is printed as a result of the call demo (1234)?

questions.question:
Consider the following pseudo-code

x:=1;
i:=1;
while (x <= 1000)
begin
    x:=2^x;
    i:=i+1;
end;

questions.question:

int i ;

{
    i = 10;
    call f();
}

procedure f()
{   
    int i = 20;
    call g ();
}
procedure g ()
{   
    print i;
}

Let x be the value printed under static scoping and y be the value printed under dynamic scoping. Then, x and y are:

(GATE IT 2007)

questions.question:
Consider the program below in a hypothetical language which allows global variable and a choice of call by reference or call by value methods of parameter passing. 

int i ;
program main ()
{
    int j = 60;
    i = 50;
    call f (i, j);
    print i, j;
}
procedure f (x, y)
{           
    i = 100;
    x = 10;
    y = y + i ;
}

Which one of the following options represents the correct output of the program for the two parameter passing mechanisms?

(GATE IT 2007)
options:
A.

Call by value : i = 70, j = 10; Call by reference :i = 60, j = 70

B.

Call by value : i = 50, j = 60; Call by reference :i = 50, j = 70

C.

Call by value : i = 10, j = 70; Call by reference :i = 100, j = 60

D.

Call by value : i = 100, j = 60; Call by reference :i = 10, j = 70
questions.correct_answer:
D.

Call by value : i = 100, j = 60; Call by reference :i = 10, j = 70
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Consider the C program given below : 

 #include < stdio.h >

int main ()    {
    int sum = 0, maxsum = 0,  i,  n = 6;
    int a [] = {2, -2, -1, 3, 4, 2};
    for (i = 0; i < n; i++)    {
            if (i == 0 || a [i]  < 0  || a [i] < a [i - 1])  {
                     if (sum > maxsum) maxsum = sum;
                     sum = (a [i] > 0) ? a [i] : 0;
            }
            else sum += a [i];
    }
    if (sum > maxsum) maxsum = sum ;
    printf ("%d\n", maxsum);

}

What is the value printed out when this program is executed?

(GATE IT 2007)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
The function f is defined as follows:

 int f (int n) {
    if (n <= 1) return 1;
    else if (n % 2  ==  0) return f(n/2);
    else return f(3n - 1);
}

Assuming that arbitrarily large integers can be passed as a parameter to the function, consider the following statements.

i. The function f terminates for finitely many different values of \(n \geq 1\).
ii. The function f terminates for infinitely many different values of \(n \geq 1\).
iii. The function f does not terminate for finitely many different values of \(n \geq 1\).
iv. The function f does not terminate for infinitely many different values of \(n \geq 1\).

Which one of the following options is true of the above?

(GATE IT 2007)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow
